content.location: On the east side of the large split boulder which is obviously visible from the parking lot. It's just uphill from the bridge once you cross. Please access from the trail to reduce erosion. Cross the bridge and turn uphill at the fork about 75 ft down the trail. Follow the switchbacks until the trail flattens out. Turn left at the T and look left for the boulder. It will be about 50 ft to your left. Approaching from this direction, you'll be looking at Wambli Slab and New Year's Reservation.

content.description: This problems climbs the offwidth/chimney on the western face of chimney rock. Sit start with a foot jammed in the OW and a right hand on the arete/ edge of the OW. Twist and grovel your way up and out of the OW.
Make techy cross over move, and stand up on thin face holds. From here, follow a series of small edges using sequencal footholds to the top.
content.location: On the south face of the large boulder 75 yards north of the Wambli Slab, on hill side just above the bridge/ baseball field, climb blank face just right of cave-like feature.

content.description: Goes up the feldspar vein on the left side of the boulder's western face.
content.location: Cross the bridge, follow the lower trail along the river until you spot the pavilion with interpretive signs. Here there is a massive boulder overhanging the trial on the left with quartz veins throughout. Hang a left straight uphill along the south side of this boulder. You should run into the still sleeping boulder after less than two minutes off trail.

content.description: This is a great finger crack. The rock is a little loose surrounding the crack, but all holds that matter are solid. It was named in memory of my nephew, Peter Jeffris, who perished on Long's.
content.protection: Pads. A landing zone can be built up with a log or two. Put a pad on top to build a landing platform. Otherwise, it is dangerous.
content.location: Take the Barbara Whipple (mountain bike) trail until you come to the kiosk. Keep heading South along the river until you are even with the Eddyline Brewery. The crack is obvious just up from the river.

content.description: Start at the far left edge of the boulder's western face where the vein peters out. Traverse right as the ground slopes up with you, which is nice when you have no spotter; could also go padless for that reason. Crux is in the first 15 feet before getting to the juggy section. A harder (V3-V4?) variation stays low and uses none of the jugs until the end of the face when you dyno to the lip (fun).
content.location:
Same as

Still Sleeping

: Cross the bridge, follow the lower trail along the river until you spot the pavilion with interpretive signs. Here there is a massive boulder overhanging the trial on the left with quartz veins throughout. Hang a left straight uphill along the south side of this boulder. You should run into the

Still Sleeping

boulder after less than two minutes off trail.

content.description: Start with left hand on the best crimper and head directly upward through balancy slab moves. You're heading for the right-facing crack which takes you to the lip.
content.location: It is best downclimb is at the Northeast corner of the boulder.

content.description:
Traverses right to left on the boulder just downhill from the

Still Sleeping

boulder. Sharp!
content.location:
See directions for

Still Sleeping

boulder. You'll walk by this one 50 ft before it.
